title: Cape Cod house with Watergate ties falls victim to eroding bluff
author: Regina Cole
bullets: Demolition of Bartlett House in Eastham began on February 3, 2026, due to severe erosion.
Bartlett House, tied to Watergate scandal, was used by Nixon's aides, including John Ehrlichman and Donald Rumsfeld.
The house was deemed unsafe due to proximity to an eroding cliff and saltwater infiltration into its well.

title: UMass Lowell wants to make the city a destination with a new rink and hotel
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: UMass Lowell plans a new ice rink and hotel to attract students, residents, and visitors to the city.
The Lowell Innovation Network Corridor aims to enhance community development with educational, business, and entertainment projects.
The university seeks proposals for the rink and hotel, following Board of Trustees approval in December.

title: Judge drops assault charge against former City Hall staffer
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Judge dropped domestic violence charge against former City Hall staffer Chulan Huang due to victim's absence in court.
Chulan Huang was fired after altercation involving his then-girlfriend and Segun Idowu, a top City Hall official.
Marwa Khudaynazar is suing Boston, alleging her firing was to protect Idowu; federal judge dismissed most of her claims.

title: This Rowley inn is the perfect place for romance
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Briar Barn Inn in Rowley named a top Valentine’s getaway by The Hotel Guru for its romantic amenities.
JetBlue and Delta ranked among the safest airlines for 2026 by AirlineRatings.com based on multiple safety criteria.
Great Wolf Lodge offers a one-day flash sale with rates of $26 per person per night for stays through June 18.

title: A dispute over a shoveled-out parking space led to a stabbing in Dorchester, police say
author: John Waller
bullets: A parking space dispute in Dorchester led to a stabbing at 1:25 a.m. near 59 Evans St.
A 41-year-old man and 47-year-old woman suffered hand injuries and were taken to local hospitals.
Enel Javier, 47, was arrested for assault and battery after allegedly stabbing the man with a knife.

title: Where to watch Super Bowl 2026 in Boston: 7 must-visit sports bars
author: Kevin Slane and Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Banners Kitchen & Tap features a 40-foot screen, DJ, and ticketed experiences with bottomless wings on Super Bowl Sunday.
Tony C’s offers numerous large TVs across its locations in Somerville, Burlington, and Peabody to view the game.
PickleBOS in South Boston combines pickleball with a Super Bowl watch party, offering open play and catered food.

title: Four charged in $1M SNAP, unemployment fraud scheme tied to Leominster restaurant
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Four people charged in $1 million fraud scheme involving stolen identities to collect SNAP and PUA benefits.
Defendants allegedly used over 100 stolen identities to create fraudulent 'households' in Massachusetts and Rhode Island.
Raul Fernandez Vicioso operated El Primo Restaurant, where funds were allegedly laundered and sent abroad.

title: Local obituary: Jaylin Rainford, 20, Catholic Memorial grad and Bryant University junior
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Jaylin Rainford, a 20-year-old Bryant University junior, passed away on January 25, 2026, leaving a strong legacy.
Rainford was a Catholic Memorial High School graduate and a finance major involved in track and field.
Visitation and funeral services for Jaylin Rainford will be held in Randolph on February 6 and 7, 2026.

title: Drake Maye says he got Super Bowl schedule advice from a former Patriots rival
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Drake Maye received Super Bowl scheduling advice from former NFL quarterback Peyton Manning before his first game.
Maye recounted attending Super Bowl 50 where Manning's Broncos defeated the Panthers 24-10 at Levi's Stadium.
Maye, a lifelong Panthers fan, appreciated advice from football legends as he prepares for Super Bowl LX with the Patriots.

title: Here’s what to expect these remaining weeks of winter, according to Dave Epstein
author: David Epstein
bullets: Boston is experiencing colder-than-average temperatures, with a significant Arctic cold blast expected in early February.
February temperatures may warm slightly mid-month before a return to colder patterns as March approaches.
Boston could see similar snowfalls to previous years, but overall dryness might limit significant precipitation.
